newsitem.title: USA: Dollar ends mixed in U.S. after official comments.
newsitem.headline: Dollar ends mixed in U.S. after official comments.

text.p: The dollar surged above 1.80 marks on Wednesday to a nearly six-year high, but ended lower after German officials said the dollar had risen too far.
The greenback rose against the yen after a key Japanese official said the market was too optimistic about the yen.
The dollar initially rose to a peak of 1.8040 marks -- its highest since August 1991 -- on fresh signs that Europe's proposed single currency may be a weak one.
German research group HWWA cut its forecast for 1997 German GDP growth and said Germany's budget deficit would exceed the target for entry into the planned single currency.

A Reuters survey showed European investors expect the euro to comprise a wide range of currencies, including many weaker units that would undermine the mark's status as Europe's leading currency, analysts said.

"The marketplace is saying the deutschemark is too high," said Mike Malpede, senior foreign exchange analyst at Refco Group, Ltd. "Until we see what will be the monetary policy for the new European Central Bank, it's hard to instill any confidence in the deutschemark."
But in New York trade the dollar fell when Bundesbank council member Franz-Christoph Zeitler told reporters in Germany that the dollar's rally may have become excessive.

Zeitler added that Germany wants a strong mark and German Finance Minister Theo Waigel later told Reuters the German cabinet will make a statement on Wednesday endorsing a strong mark and a strong euro.
"Those comments seemed to drag the dollar down," said James Powers, vice president for corporate foreign exchange at Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale.
The dollar fell to 1.7930/40 marks from 1.7940/45 at the open, but rose to 115.74/79 yen from 114.38/43.
Profit-taking in dollar/mark actually began just before the late German comments and some dealers began to lose faith in the greenback's recent rally.

"The fact that we were unable to break 1.8030-35 was basically the reason why we came back. This might actually be the signal that this is the top," said Edith Wolf, head of currency sales at Credit Commerciale de France.
Wolf said she sees a possible period of consolidation between 1.7850 and 1.8035 marks.
The dollar rallied in Asia when a news wire quoted Japan's vice minister for international affairs Eisuke Sakakibara saying market expectations of yen strength were too high.
Sakakibara also said G7 leaders would not use foreign exchange rates as a tool to manipulate trade flows.
"If Japan can keep the dollar a little higher against the yen, perhaps Japan's recovery can become a little more solid," said Malpede.
The steady flow of offical German objections to the dollar's gains prompted concerns that monetary authorities might enter the market to support the mark.
In fact, the Bank of Italy for the second straight day bought marks against the Italian lira, dealers said.

"The German comments are suggesting that they are starting to really watch this and that they don't want it to get away from them," said Anjum Sayyed, currency dealer at Manufacturers and Traders Bank.

Elsewhere, the dollar rose to 1.4730/40 Swiss francs from 1.4717/22 and rose to Canadian $1.3700/05 from C$$1.3670/75. The British pound fell to $1.6783/93 from $1.6848/55. The Australian dollar fell to $0.7349/54 from $0.7358/68.
